title: Woman’s foot starts to rot away after bug bite in Benidorm
text:
Faye Wilkes, 41, had to fly home and rush to hospital after contracting a flesh-eating bug (Picture: SWNS)

A woman almost lost her leg after she was bitten by an unknown bug while sunbathing on holiday.

Faye Wilkes, 41, watched in agony as the flesh on her left foot began rotting away.

She was holidaying in Benidorm, Spain, when she felt a ‘sharp nip’ on her foot as she sat by the pool.

A red mark instantly appeared but Faye thought it was a common mosquito and thought nothing of it.

The holiday had been booked as a treat for Faye and her sister, Carrie, 43, after the death of their father Raymond, 66.

Faye said: ‘We recently lost our dad to lung cancer and to cheer ourselves up, unwind and relax my sister and I booked a holiday.

‘We hoped to spend a week soaking up the sun and sipping cocktails, but it turned into a holiday from hell.’

Four days into her trip the personal assistant, from Dartford, Kent, started to worry as her leg began to swell.

Warning: graphic image below

Faye Wilkes, 41, felt a ‘sharp nip’ on her foot but thought nothing more of it (Picture: SWNS)

Faye’s injured foot as she recovered in the Royal Surrey Hospital (Picture: SWNS)

She struggled to put any weight on it but claims medics turned her away from a hospital in Spain because they thought she was a ‘typical drunk Brit’.

The mum-of-one had to cut her family holiday short and fly back to the UK to get help.

At this point the mum-of-one’s foot was blistered and infected.

She was rushed to intensive care at Royal Surrey Hospital straight from Gatwick Airport where doctors told her she had contracted a flesh-eating bug likely to have come from a spider bite.

Doctors diagnosed Faye with sepsis and warned her that if she had left the infection any longer, she may have been forced to undergo an amputation.

She said: ‘I was absolutely horrified, as I didn’t think a measly bite from a bug in Benidorm would result in sepsis, let alone the loss of my leg.

‘Luckily, they were able to flush out the infection without having to do any invasive surgery, but I still feel incredibly weak.

‘They couldn’t find the bug in my system, so were unable to work out which one caused me to have sepsis, but I’m glad that I went to the hospital when I did, as I was close to death.’

Faye with her sister, Carrie (left) and her mum, before her ordeal (Picture: SWNS)

Faye took a picture of her legs on holiday before the bite (Picture: SWNS)

Faye with her late dad Raymond (Picture: SWNS)

Faye had to spend four months in intensive care and is now recovering at home but still has the scars from the agonising blisters she developed.

She said: ‘Although they got rid of the infection, my foot and leg is still scarred and my circulation is awful, so I have to keep it propped up near enough 24/7.

‘I think it was either a dirty spider or mosquito that brought this pain and distress upon me – but I will never know.

‘The main thing is that I’m alive and I still have my left leg and foot – but I know I still have a long way to go until I’m out of the woods.

‘I had to learn to walk again and build up my strength.’
